HUMAN PREFERENCES IN LARGE LANGUAGE MODEL LATENT SPACE

This study analyzes the reliability of synthetic data generated by large language models (LLMs) in predicting voting outcomes. The researchers evaluate 14 different LLMs and find that they fail to replicate the variance observed in real-world human responses, particularly across demographic subgroups. They also show that prompt sensitivity can significantly alter outputs for some models.

Key Concepts:

  • Validity of synthetic data
  • Demographic attributes
  • Prompt variations
  • LLM-generated responses
  • Latent Space Persona-to-Party Mapping
  • Synthetic Distribution of Political Ascription
  • Human Preferences in Language Model Latent Space
  • Voting distributions
  • Center-left parties
  • Left-leaning parties
Generative AI Large Language Models Survey Data Reliability Latent Space Wahl-o-Mat German elections European elections party manifestos voting recommendation
